data.title: Charles Darwin's Scientific Theory of Evolution - 1284 Words
data.meta_description: Free Essay: Charles Darwin is well-known for his groundbreaking work on evolutionary biology. Among his many contributions, The Origin of Species is the most...
data.text:
Charles Darwin is well-known for his groundbreaking work on evolutionary biology. Among his many contributions, The Origin of Species is the most associated with his name. He introduces the scientific theory of evolution and suggests that species have evolved over a period of many generations through a process called natural selection. Darwin's theories have created much controversy among his colleagues and led to great amounts of debate. However, the massive amount of criticism directed at Darwin convinced him to make to revisions. As a result, his future editions would differ considerably from the earlier versions and he also responds to some of the issues people had with his theory in the later versions. Unfortunately, his adjustments …show more content…

The evidence that supports this argument is from numerical calculations that were designed to demonstrate the potential rate of increase in population that must be checked by the shortage of resources.

The “survival of the fittest” situation is usually applied in the aspect of members of the same species fighting against each other. Darwin claims that there are many different factors determine survival and the reason a member may not survive is often outside of its power. For example, many members of a species are eliminated before they are fully grown. Factors such as food shortages or predators are the most common examples. This relationship does not just exist within exist within one group of species. Darwin emphasizes that they there is a complex web shared between species as many are held in check by certain predators while also treating some other species as prey. This idea was impressive as Darwin introduced this fascinating new concept that was generally accepted even by people that did not agree with his first theory of natural selection. Darwin was also cautious in his wording as he described this new concept of his as he did not want his book to be viewed as an amoral view of nature. He finishes his ideas in this area with “When we reflect on this struggle, we may console ourselves with the full belief that the war of nature is
